answers: Safety helmets, proper ventilation, and training on emergency procedures are crucial for coal mining safety.
Safety inspections should be conducted regularly, ideally on a daily basis, to ensure compliance with safety regulations.
Personal protective equipment (PPE) such as hard hats, safety boots, and respirators are essential for safety in coal mines.
Common hazards in coal mining include gas explosions, roof collapses, and exposure to harmful gases like methane.

The key Acts and Rules governing the Mining Industry in India include: The Coal Mines Act, 1952; Indian Explosives Act, 1884; Colliery Control Order, 2000; Colliery Control Rules, 2004; The Coal Mines Regulations, 2017; and The Payment of Wages (Mines) Rules, 1956.
The Coal Mines Act, 1952, regulates the working conditions, safety, and welfare of laborers in coal mines.
The Indian Explosives Act, 1884, governs the handling, storage, and use of explosives, which are often used in mining operations.
The Colliery Control Order and Rules cover various aspects of colliery management, safety, and operational procedures in coal mines.
The Coal Mines Regulations, 2017, set detailed standards for safety, health, and environmental protection in coal mining.
Wages in mining are regulated by The Payment of Wages (Mines) Rules, 1956, which specify the rules for the payment of wages to mine workers.
Yes, land-related laws like CRA (Coal Bearing Areas Act), LA (Land Acquisition Act), and RandR (Rehabilitation and Resettlement) laws can also be relevant to mining projects.
You can consult official government websites, legal authorities, or contact the Ministry of Coal for detailed information on mining laws and regulations.
To stay updated on changes in mining laws, it's advisable to regularly check official government websites and subscribe to relevant industry publications for updates.
Yes, the Ministry of Coal has developed a chatbot using AI and NLP technology to answer queries related to mining laws, acts, and regulations.
The essence of federalism lies in the sharing of legal sovereignty between the Union and the federating units, primarily through the demarcation of legislative powers.

Article 245 of the Indian Constitution specifies that Parliament may make laws for the whole or any part of the territory of India, while the legislature of a State may make laws for the whole or any part of the State.

Article 246 delineates the distribution of legislative powers, stating Parliament's exclusive power over matters in List 1 (Union List), while both Parliament and State Legislatures have power over matters in List III (Concurrent List), and State Legislatures have exclusive power over matters in List II (State List).
The co-existence of Central and State laws can lead to litigation due to illegal encroachment by one legislature into the province of the other or clashes between laws.

Conflicting laws between the Union and States outside the Concurrent List are addressed by determining legislative competence, with one of the laws being void due to exclusive jurisdiction conferred by the Constitution.
When legislation by both the Union and States pertains to subjects in the Concurrent List, the test of repugnancy under Article 254(2) of the Constitution is applied.
The view upheld regarding the application of the test of repugnancy is that it is relevant only in matters of Concurrent List legislation, as per various decisions by the Supreme Court.

The four salient features include a three-fold distribution represented by Union, State, and Concurrent lists, supremacy of federal laws in certain situations, vesting of residuary law-making power in the federation, and situations where the federation may be vested with legislative power even on state subjects.

The All India coal production in 2021-22 was 778.21 million tonnes, showing a positive growth. In 2022-23, the production increased to 893.19 million tonnes, marking a growth of 14.77% compared to the previous year.

Coal India Limited (CIL) and its subsidiaries produced 622.63 million tonnes of coal in 2021-22, indicating a positive growth of 4.4% from the previous year. In 2022-23, CIL's coal production increased to 703.20 million tonnes, with a growth of 12.94%.

Singareni Collieries Company Limited (SCCL) is the main source of coal for the southern region. In 2021-22, SCCL produced 65.02 million tonnes of coal, which increased to 67.14 million tonnes in 2022-23, showing a positive growth of 3.26%.

The Marketing Division of Coal India Limited (CIL) coordinates marketing activities for all its subsidiaries. It has established Regional Sales Offices and Sub-Sales Offices across the country to meet the needs of various consuming sectors.
According to the present import policy, coal can be freely imported by consumers themselves under Open General Licence, based on their commercial considerations.
Coking coal is primarily imported by the steel sector to bridge the gap between the requirement and indigenous availability and to improve quality.

The Ministry of Coal is responsible for determining policies and strategies related to the exploration and development of coal and lignite reserves, sanctioning important projects, and addressing related issues through Public Sector Undertakings (PSUs) like Coal India Ltd. and Neyveli Lignite Corporation India Ltd.

The Sustainable Development Cell (SDC) established by the Ministry of Coal aims to promote environmentally sustainable coal mining in the country and address concerns during mining operations until decommissioning or final closure of mines.

The Sustainability & Just Transition (S & JT) Division within the Ministry of Coal advises, mentors, plans, and monitors mitigation measures for sustainable resource utilization, environmental impact reduction, and just transition principles in the coal sector.

The thrust areas identified by the S & JT Division for sustainable coal mining include land amelioration and afforestation, air quality and emission management, mine water management, gainful use of overburden, sustainable mine tourism, planning, monitoring, and auditing, as well as policy, research, education, and dissemination.

Initiatives undertaken by coal companies for greening the coal sector include ecological reclamation of mined-out land, extensive plantation in and around coal-bearing areas, and restoration of flora and fauna to minimize the environmental footprint of mining operations.

Energy efficiency measures implemented by coal/lignite PSUs include replacing conventional lights with LED lights, using energy-efficient appliances, installation of capacitor banks, deployment of e-vehicles, and various energy conservation initiatives.

Coal India Limited (CIL) has signed an MOU with Energy Efficiency Services Limited (EESL) to implement energy efficiency programs, including building energy efficiency projects, replacement of old appliances with energy-efficient ones, and deployment of distributed and rooftop solar projects.
